Korean Judoist wins gold medal
articles.content:
Korean Judoist wins gold medal
    Pyongyang, June 27 (KCNA) -- DPRK Judoist Kwak Ok Chol reportedly won the match in the men's 81 kg division of the 1999 Asian Judo Championships held in China on June 25.

articles.title: Military provocations of S. Korean authorities denounced
articles.content:
Military provocations of S. Korean authorities denounced
   Pyongyang, June 27 (KCNA) -- The Unionist Socialist Party of Syria on June 20 released a statement denouncing the military provocations of South Korean authorities in the West Sea of Korea.
   The statement said the party and the Syrian Arab people strongly condemn the South Korean authorities for committing   military provocations against the DPRK under the protection of the U.S. 
   It expressed full support for all efforts General Secretary Kim  Jong Il has made for peace of the Korean peninsula and peaceful reunification of the country.
   If peace is to be ensured in the peninsula, the U.S. should renounce their policy of hostility toward the Korean people.

Humiliating solicitation
articles.content:
Humiliating solicitation
   Pyongyang, June 27 (KCNA) -- A top-ranking official of Japan recently asked a senior official of a country to inform the DPRK of Japan's apprehensions, including "a missile launch issue."    Rodong Sinmun today describes the humiliating solicitation as deep-seated bad habit of the Japanese authorities who have tried to get something with the backing of a big country.   
   The news analyst says:   More than once Japan asked others to meddle in the outstanding issues between the DPRK and Japan only to be rejected by the DPRK.  It has not yet broken with the bad habit, though.   We consider this humiliating diplomacy as a foolish act reminiscent of a drowning man catching at a straw.
   It is more absurd of the Japanese authorities to think we may lend an ear to somebody's words.   
   The DPRK deems independence its life and soul. We flatly reject what others say, if it violates our sovereignty and if it offends us. 
   Our dignity and sovereignty remain unchanged, not affected by what a big country or a small country says.
   No one can undermine such a stand of ours. 
   What must be called into question in northeast Asia is not "missile launch" by the DPRK, but Japan's attempts at overseas aggression.
